sub_topic: De Rham cohomology and its applications
message_1: Compute the first De Rham cohomology group of the torus $T^2$ with the flat metric.
message_2:
To compute the first De Rham cohomology group of the torus $T^2$ with the flat metric, we will first need to understand the De Rham cohomology groups in general. The De Rham cohomology groups are a way to study the topology of a manifold using differential forms. They measure the failure of exactness in the sequence of differential forms.

The torus $T^2$ can be described as the quotient space $\mathbb{R}^2 / \mathbb{Z}^2$, where $\mathbb{Z}^2$ is the lattice generated by two linearly independent vectors in $\mathbb{R}^2$. We can represent the torus as the square $[0, 1] \times [0, 1]$ with opposite sides identified.

Now, let's compute the first De Rham cohomology group $H^1(T^2)$. We will use the fact that the De Rham cohomology groups are isomorphic to the singular cohomology groups with real coefficients, i.e., $H^k_{dR}(M) \cong H^k(M; \mathbb{R})$ for a smooth manifold $M$.

The singular cohomology groups of the torus are well-known: $H^0(T^2) = \mathbb{R}$, $H^1(T^2) = \mathbb{R}^2$, $H^2(T^2) = \mathbb{R}$, and all other cohomology groups are trivial. Therefore, the first De Rham cohomology group of the torus is $H^1_{dR}(T^2) \cong H^1(T^2; \mathbb{R}) = \mathbb{R}^2$.

This result can be interpreted as follows: there are two linearly independent closed 1-forms on the torus that are not exact, which generate the first De Rham cohomology group. These 1-forms can be thought of as the "winding numbers" around the two non-contractible loops of the torus.
